summary:

Island and Coastal Archaeology, Landscape Archaeology, Prospective Archaeology, Applied Archaeology, Archaeological Survey, Caribbean Archaeology, Ceramics.

For publication downloads and biography details, please visit:
https://leidenuni.academia.edu/MaaikeDeWaal

awards.title: First prize for landscape project design '6000 years Blaricummermeent' (category non-profit, non-student)
awards.description:
At the borders of Blaricum and adjacent to the Gooimeer the project De Blaricummermeent is being developed. This is a large development project of which the full implementation has been severely delayed as a result of the economic crisis. This has resulted in Wachtend Land (Waiting Land), temporary wasteland with opportunities for temporary use! The contest for developing plans for this waiting land results in the combination of history, art, bees and trees at the squares in the Blaricummermeent! (www.wachtendland.nl)

ARGEOgraph designed in cooperation with Pica Archeologie a plan, inspired on previous results of archaeological investigations by Maaike de Waal and Kirsten Leijnse (as RAAP Archeologisch Adviesbureau employees) in the Blaricummermeent. These investigations had revealed an intact Pleistocene landscape that had been used intensively during the Stone Age. The project design, aimed at education and recreation to remember and experience this past landscape use. ARGEOgraph and Pica Archeologie won the first prize in the category non-profit/non-student with their project '6000 years Blaricummermeent'.
awards.issuer: Wachtend Land (municipality of Blaricum, Urban Management, Polis, Delft University of Technology & De Blaricummermeent)

profile_positions.title: Assistant professor & head of Field Research Education Centre, Faculty of Archaeology
Lecturer and Coordinator Honours College, Faculty of Archaeology, Leiden University

profile_positions.description:
- Working on a wide range of contract projects focusing on archaeology and geoinformatics in archaeology (the latter together with geodetic engineer Jochem Lesparre), both related to the Netherlands as well as the Caribbean
- Responsible for all administrative matters related to working as an independent archaeologist
 - Responsible for acquisition and organisation of the projects

Examples of projects carried out:
- Creating archaeological predictive maps of Saba and St. Eustatius (for St. Eustatius Center for Archaeological Research)
- Evaluating archaeological research projects on St. Eustatius (for Dutch Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment)
- Composing technical research reports as senior archaeologist (for Transect, Utrecht and for Bureau Archeologie en Monumentenzorg, City of Almere, both in the Netherlands)
- Supervising archaeology student internships (for Saxion University of Applied Sciences, Deventer, the Netherlands)
- Topographic surveying of archaeological sites in the Netherlands (for Saxion University of Applied Sciences, Deventer, the Netherlands)
- Replacing the team lead of an archaeological excavation team (for RAAP Archeologisch Adviesbureau, Leiden, the Netherlands)
- Designing (and becoming first prize winner in the category non-profit / non-student) a temporary (5-10 years) archaeological park called  “6000 years Blaricummermeent” at the location of an area to be developed in Blaricum (with Pica Archeologie; for Wachtend Land Ideeëncompetitie gemeente Blaricum; http://www.wachtendland.nl/Ideeencompetitie/default.aspx)

www.argeograph.nl

profile_positions.description:
- Designing, teaching and assessing lectures, tutorials (Academic Skills) and teaching practical courses (analysis of excavated materials). Lectures include World Archaeology 2, The Americas (BA1), Hunter-Gatherers and Early Farmers in the Near East and the Caribbean (BA2) and BA-thesis course (BA3)
- Developing course instructions on Blackboard

profile_positions.title: Assistant professor in (Caribbean) archaeology

profile_positions.description:
- Heading the prospection team of RAAP region West (ca. 10 persons), including the responsibility relating to HRM matters (interviews, contracts, personal and professional monitoring and coaching)
- Co-developing prospective research projects for the team: coring projects to map past landscapes and human presence in these landscapes
- Responsible, as senior project manager, for acquisition, organisation, supervision and authorisation of all research projects in the field of prospection archaeology by the team mentioned above
- Reviewing and editing the reports resulting from the projects mentioned above
- Responsible, as head of the prospection team, for obtaining contract project money (CRM projects) with and for RAAP Wests prospection team from government agencies and private initiators
- Communicating archaeological results to government agencies (local, provincial and national), to private initiators, to the general public and to the archaeological community
- Contribution to increasing efficiency in project work
profile_positions.title: Team lead archaeological prospection

profile_positions.description:

- Functioning as examiner for the course Archaeological Research Methods I

company.name: The University of the West Indies

profile_positions.company: The University of the West Indies
profile_positions.description:
- Designing and creating an archaeology minor for the Department of History and Philosophy
- Developing and teaching lectures and tutorials for the courses Introduction to Archaeology (including History of Archaeology and Archaeological Theory), World Prehistory, Archaeological Research Methods and Techniques and Caribbean Archaeology
- Co-developing and co-teaching lectures and tutorials for the course Geoinformatics in Archaeology (with Jochem Lesparre, geodetic engineer)
- Functioning as examiner for the courses Introduction to Archaeology, World Prehistory, Archaeological Research Methods and Techniques and Caribbean Archaeology
- Developing course instructions on the UWI digital learning environment

Additional activities undertaken included:
- Developing and teaching practical courses related to the courses Archaeological Research Methods and Techniques and Caribbean Archaeology
- Developing, teaching and supervising fieldschools (surface surveys and test excavations in Barbados, using a landscape/geographical approach)
- Co-authoring the self-assessment departmental report and functioning as committee member during the official Departmental review (Department of History and Philosophy, University of the West Indies, April 2009)
- Presenting on archaeology as a job during the 2009 National Career Showcase for school children (Barbados, April 2009)
- Presenting and contributing to excursions and analyses of private archaeological collections during the Amerindian Archaeology Week (Barbados Museum and Historical Society; 23 - 27 November 2009)
- Setting up an archaeology laboratory and creating coral and shell reference collections at University of the West Indies, Barbados
profile_positions.title: Lecturer in Archaeology, department of History and Philosophy, Cave Hill Campus, Barbados

profile_positions.description:
- Designing, doing, supervising and reporting archaeological research in the Netherlands, including surface surveys, coring investigations (both by hand and mechanically), watching briefs and test excavations at prehistoric, Roman, medieval or post- medieval archaeological sites and trying to reconstruct (parts of) past landscapes and the presence of humans in these landscapes (for relevant publications select ‘publications’, select years 2004-2007 at http://archaeology.leiden.edu/organisation/staff/waaldsde.html#publications-category-grouper)
- Creating archaeological predictive maps
- Carrying out literature studies and creating advisory documents for provinces, local authorities and private clients
- Designing programmes of requirements for literature and archival research, for archaeological watching briefs, auger testing investigations (by hand and by aqualock- and avegaar machines) and test excavations, for provinces, local authorities and private clients

I also gained knowledge and experience with regards to:
- Archaeological legislation and regulations 
- Efficient and flexible project and data management
- Making archaeological data accessible to the general public by writing accessible reports about archaeological fieldwork for archaeologists and non-archaeologists at provinces, local authorities and private clients
profile_positions.title: Field archaeologist and archaeological consultant

profile_positions.description:
Investigating pre-Columbian interaction in (a small part of) the Caribbean through the analysis of archaeological settlement patterns;
Teaching theoretical and practical courses and fieldschools.

Check out, download or order dissertation:
http://www.maaike.lesparre-dewaal.nl/dissertation.htm

- Carrying out a four year PhD project I had designed myself (granted by Leiden University)
- Designing and carrying out three field campaigns (3-4 months each) to obtain data for PhD project
- Writing and compiling PhD dissertation

Additional activities undertaken included:
- Writing grant proposals (French Ministry of Culture) in order to finance PhD fieldwork campaigns
- Lecturing and examining
- Developing and teaching practical classes (analysis and documentation of excavated materials)
- Teaching fieldschools (Guadeloupe)
- Participating in Archon Research School of Archaeology courses
- Contributing to the national ‘Carte Archéologique’ project (French Ministry of Culture)
- Compiling extensive yearly reports on fieldwork carried out (for French Ministry of Culture)
- Writing grant proposals (Prins Bernard Foundation, Leiden University Fund and Dutch Organisation for Scientific Research) in order to participate in national and international congresses
- Writing grant proposals (Dutch Organisation for Scientific Research) allow specialist analysis of faunal remains recovered during PhD fieldwork campaigns
- Design and lay-out of PhD dissertation into book format
- Writing grant proposals (J.E. Jurriaanse Stichting and Foundation for Anthropology and Prehistory in the Netherlands) for publication of PhD dissertation (2006)
- Compiling publications, including a book chapters (1999), published conference papers (1999, 2003), journal articles (2 x in 1999, 2000, 2001) and reports (2 x in 1998, 3 x in 1999, 2002)
